objectives.description: Recognize how time horizon affects investment strategy and why different goals require different approaches.

leftPanel.title: Your Blueprint for Financial Strategy
paragraphs: How you save and invest depends on when you need the money. This is the most important factor in choosing a strategy.
Short-term (1-3 years): Favor safety and liquidity‚Äîyou can't afford to lose value right before you need it.
Medium-term (3-10 years): Balance growth and protection‚Äîsome risk is acceptable.
Long-term (10+ years): Focus on growth potential‚Äîtime to recover from market dips.

highlightBox.text: ‚è±Ô∏è The longer your time horizon, the more risk you can afford to take!

layoutData.title: Your Comfort Level with Uncertainty
paragraphs: Risk tolerance is personal‚Äîit depends on your age, financial situation, goals, and personality. Understanding yourself helps you choose investments you can stick with.
bulletPoints: Conservative: Prioritizes protection of principal. Accepts lower returns to avoid losses. Better for those near retirement or needing money soon.
Moderate: Balanced approach. Accepts some market volatility for better long-term returns. Most common for mid-career investors.
Aggressive: Focuses on maximum growth. Can tolerate significant short-term losses. Best for young investors with long time horizons.
Key insight: Your risk tolerance should match your time horizon‚Äîlonger horizon = can handle more risk

keyPoint.text: üéØ The best investment strategy is one you'll actually stick with through market ups and downs!

content.headerTitle: Diversification: Don't Put All Eggs in One Basket

leftPanel.title: Reducing Risk Through Variety
paragraphs: Diversification means spreading your investments across different asset types, industries, and regions.
When one investment goes down, others may go up‚Äîsmoothing out your overall returns and reducing the impact of any single loss.
It's one of the few "free lunches" in investing: you can reduce risk without necessarily sacrificing returns.

highlightBox.text: ü•ö If you put all your money in one company's stock and it fails, you lose everything. Diversify to protect yourself!

infoCard.title: Ways to Diversify:
items: Use index funds or ETFs for instant diversity

layoutData.title: The Right Tool for the Right Job
paragraphs: Different goals require different strategies. Match your investment vehicles to your timeline and risk tolerance.
bulletPoints: Short-Term (1-3 years): Emergency fund, vacation, car ‚Üí High-yield savings, money market, short-term CDs. Very low risk.
Medium-Term (3-10 years): House down payment, grad school ‚Üí Mix of CDs, bonds, conservative funds. Low to moderate risk.
Long-Term (10+ years): Retirement, child's college ‚Üí Diverse portfolio of stocks, bonds, index funds. Moderate to aggressive risk.
Very Long-Term (20+ years): Financial independence ‚Üí Stock-heavy portfolio, ride out all volatility. Focus on growth.

keyPoint.text: üìÖ The closer you are to needing the money, the more you should prioritize safety over growth!

leftPanel.title: Start Now, Adjust as You Go
paragraphs: Your financial strategy isn't set in stone‚Äîit should evolve as your life changes. What works at 20 won't work at 50.
The key is to start with a plan that matches your current situation, then adjust as your time horizon shortens or your goals change.
Many people use target-date funds that automatically shift from aggressive to conservative as retirement approaches.

highlightBox.text: � The most important step? Start investing NOW. Even small amounts compound dramatically over time!

scenario.name: Alex's Short-Term Car Savings Strategy in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Goal: Save $15,000 for a car in 3 years
Time Horizon: Short-term (3 years)
Risk Tolerance: Conservative‚Äîcan't risk losing money before purchase
Strategy: 60% high-yield savings account, 40% short-term CDs
Rationale: Alex needs certainty about the amount available in 3 years. Market downturns could derail the goal‚Äîsafety comes first for short-term needs.

scenario.name: Taylor's Long-Term Retirement Strategy in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Goal: Build retirement savings over 40 years
Time Horizon: Long-term (40 years)
Risk Tolerance: Moderately aggressive‚Äîyoung, can handle volatility
Strategy: Diversified portfolio: 70% index funds (stocks), 30% bonds
Rationale: With 40 years to invest, Taylor can ride out market downturns. Needs growth to outpace inflation. Will gradually shift to more bonds as retirement approaches.
